maml:description.maml:para: Backup-AzADSecurityGroup cmdlet to backup Azure Active Directory security groups.
Backup-AzADSecurityGroup cmdlet helps to backup Azure Active Directory security groups and it's members. It takes the backup of role assignments of the security groups for complete restoration.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the number of background jobs to run.
Runs the backup as background job.
Takes an incremental backup. This means if there are any new groups added, this cmdlet looks for new changes and adds it to the backup database.
Returns the output.
Runs the backup as background job.
Takes an incremental backup. This means if there are any new groups added, this cmdlet looks for new changes and adds it to the backup database.
Specify the number of background jobs to run.
Returns the output.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
# Take a full backup PS C:\> Backup-AzADSecurityGroup -Verbose
# Take an incremental backup PS C:\> Backup-AzADSecurityGroup -Incremental -Verbose
# Run backup as a background job PS C:\> Backup-AzADSecurityGroup -AsJob -Verbose

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Find-Group to get the scanned group details.
Find-Group is a helper function to get the group(s) details of all scanned security groups.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true lists all scanned groups.
Pass the group id to get the group details.
Finds group by display name.
Finds group(s) for given name pattern.
If true lists all scanned groups.
Pass the group id to get the group details.
Finds group by display name.
Finds group(s) for given name pattern.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
PS C:\> Find-Group -All # Lists all the scanned group
PS C:\> Find-Group -Name 'test-group' # Gets the group by name
PS C:\> Find-Group -NamePattern 'test' # Lists all groups with name test
PS C:\> Find-Group -Id 'xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx' # Gets the group by id

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Find-GroupMemberShip helps to find the members in the given group.
Find-GroupMemberShip helper function lists the members in a given group.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass the group id to list the members.
Pass the group name to list the members from scanned group.
Lists the members from scanned groups for passed name pattern.
Pass the group id to list the members.
Pass the group name to list the members from scanned group.
Lists the members from scanned groups for passed name pattern.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
PS C:\> Find-GroupMembership -Name 'test-group'

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Find-RoleAssignment gets the role assignment for scanned groups.

Find-RoleAssignment gets the role assignment for scanned groups. You should run `Get-AzRoleAssignment` to get the details of role assignments. This cmdlet is helper function that has a backup of role assignments for only scanned security groups.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true lists all scanned role assignments.
Get the role assignments by group id.
Get the role assignments by group name.
Get the role assignments by group name pattern.
If true lists all scanned role assignments.
Get the role assignments by group id.
Get the role assignments by group name.
Get the role assignments by group name pattern.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
PS C:\> Find-RoleAssignment -Name 'test-group'

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Find-User function to find the user from scanned backup file.
Find-User function to find the user from scanned backup file.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true lists all scanned users.
Gets a user by email.
Finds a user by id.
Finds a user by name.
Get user details for the given name pattern.
Get the user by user principal name.
If true lists all scanned users.
Gets a user by email.
Finds a user by id.
Finds a user by name.
Get user details for the given name pattern.
Get the user by user principal name.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
PS C:\> Find-User -Name 'user-name'

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Find-UserMembership helper function to get the users' group membership details.
Find-UserMembership helper function to get the users' group membership details.

maml:Description.maml:para: Find the user membership by id.
Find the user membership by user name.
Gets the membership details for passed user name pattern.
Find the user membership by id.
Find the user membership by user name.
Gets the membership details for passed user name pattern.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
PS C:\> Find-UserMembership -Name 'user-name'

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Restore-AzADSecurityGroup helps to restore the deleted security group(s) from backup.
Restore-AzADSecurityGroup helps to restore the deleted security group(s) from backup. You can either restore all the deleted groups or restore a particular group.

maml:Description.maml:para: Display name of the security group.
If true restores all the security groups.
Display name of the security group.
If true restores all the security groups.

maml:alert.maml:para: The account you are using should have necessary permissions to perform the restore action.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# Set the backup path first PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath $PWD.Path
# Restore all the deleted security groups PS C:\> Restore-AzADSecurityGroup -RestoreAll -Verbose
# Restore a particular security group PS C:\> Restore-AzADSecurityGroup -GroupDisplayName 'new-group-to-restore' -Verbose

dev:remarks.maml:para: You should set the backup path before running this cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Set-BackupPath sets the path where the backup files should be created.
Set-BackupPath sets the path where the backup files should be created.

maml:Description.maml:para: File path to store the backup files.
File path to store the backup files.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> mkdir "Azure-AD-Backup_$(Get-Date -Format yyyyMMdd_HHmmss)" PS C:\> Set-BackupPath -FilePath ".\Azure-AD-Backup_$(Get-Date -Format yyyyMMdd_HHmmss)"

dev:remarks.maml:para: By default the name of backup database will be created as 'Azure-AD-Backup.db' and you just have to specify the path to store the backup files.
